events.text:
January 1
Czechoslovakia ceases to exist as the Czech Republic and Slovakia separate in the so-called Velvet Divorce.
The European Economic Community eliminates trade barriers and creates a European single market.
events.html:
January 1
  • Czechoslovakia ceases to exist as the Czech Republic and Slovakia separate in the so-called Velvet Divorce.
  • The European Economic Community eliminates trade barriers and creates a European single market.

events.text: Czechoslovakia ceases to exist as the Czech Republic and Slovakia separate in the so-called Velvet Divorce.
events.html: Czechoslovakia ceases to exist as the Czech Republic and Slovakia separate in the so-called Velvet Divorce.

events.text: The European Economic Community eliminates trade barriers and creates a European single market.
events.html: The European Economic Community eliminates trade barriers and creates a European single market.

events.text: January 2 – Sri Lankan Civil War: The Sri Lanka Navy kills 35–100 civilians on the Jaffna Lagoon.
events.html: January 2 – Sri Lankan Civil War: The Sri Lanka Navy kills 35–100 civilians on the Jaffna Lagoon.

events.text: January 3 – In Moscow, Presidents George H. W. Bush (United States) and Boris Yeltsin (Russia) sign the second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty.
events.html: January 3 – In Moscow, Presidents George H. W. Bush (United States) and Boris Yeltsin (Russia) sign the second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty.

events.text:
January 5
US$7.4 million is stolen from the Brink's Armored Car Depot in Rochester, New York, in the fifth largest robbery in U.S. history.
MV Braer, a Liberian-registered oil tanker, runs aground off the Scottish island of Mainland, Shetland, causing a massive oil spill.
events.html:
January 5
  • US$7.4 million is stolen from the Brink's Armored Car Depot in Rochester, New York, in the fifth largest robbery in U.S. history.
  • MV Braer, a Liberian-registered oil tanker, runs aground off the Scottish island of Mainland, Shetland, causing a massive oil spill.

events.text:
January 6
Douglas Hurd is the first high-ranking British official to visit Argentina since the Falklands War.
January 6–20 – The Bombay riots take place in Mumbai.
events.html:
January 6
  • Douglas Hurd is the first high-ranking British official to visit Argentina since the Falklands War.
  • January 6–20 – The Bombay riots take place in Mumbai.

events.text: January 6–20 – The Bombay riots take place in Mumbai.
events.html: January 6–20 – The Bombay riots take place in Mumbai.

events.text: January 7 – The Fourth Republic of Ghana is inaugurated, with Jerry Rawlings as president.
events.html: January 7 – The Fourth Republic of Ghana is inaugurated, with Jerry Rawlings as president.

events.text: January 8–17 – The Braer Storm of January 1993, the most intense extratropical cyclone on record for the northern Atlantic Ocean, occurs.
events.html: January 8–17 – The Braer Storm of January 1993, the most intense extratropical cyclone on record for the northern Atlantic Ocean, occurs.

events.text:
January 13
The Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC) is signed.
U.S. Navy, Air Force, R.A.F. and French jets attack air defence sites in Southern Iraq in response to violations of the 32nd Parallel by Iraq.
events.html:
January 13
  • The Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC) is signed.
  • U.S. Navy, Air Force, R.A.F. and French jets attack air defence sites in Southern Iraq in response to violations of the 32nd Parallel by Iraq.

events.text: The Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC) is signed.

events.text: U.S. Navy, Air Force, R.A.F. and French jets attack air defence sites in Southern Iraq in response to violations of the 32nd Parallel by Iraq.
events.html: U.S. Navy, Air Force, R.A.F. and French jets attack air defence sites in Southern Iraq in response to violations of the 32nd Parallel by Iraq.

events.text: January 14 – The Polish ferry MS Jan Heweliusz sinks off the coast of Rügen in the Baltic Sea, killing 54 people.
events.html: January 14 – The Polish ferry MS Jan Heweliusz sinks off the coast of Rügen in the Baltic Sea, killing 54 people.

events.text: January 19 -  Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq refuses to allow UNSCOM inspectors to use its own aircraft to fly into Iraq and begins military operations in the demilitarized zone between Iraq and Kuwait, and the northern Iraqi no-fly zones. U.S. forces fire approximately 40 Tomahawk cruise missiles at Baghdad factories linked to Iraq's illegal nuclear weapons program. Iraq then informs UNSCOM that it will be able to resume its flights.
events.html: January 19 - Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq refuses to allow UNSCOM inspectors to use its own aircraft to fly into Iraq and begins military operations in the demilitarized zone between Iraq and Kuwait, and the northern Iraqi no-fly zones. U.S. forces fire approximately 40 Tomahawk cruise missiles at Baghdad factories linked to Iraq's illegal nuclear weapons program. Iraq then informs UNSCOM that it will be able to resume its flights.

events.text: January 20 – Bill Clinton is sworn in as the 42nd President of the United States.
events.html: January 20 – Bill Clinton is sworn in as the 42nd President of the United States.

events.text: January 24 – In Turkey, thousands protest against the murder of journalist Uğur Mumcu.
events.html: January 24 – In Turkey, thousands protest against the murder of journalist Uğur Mumcu.

events.text: January 25 – Social Democrat Poul Nyrup Rasmussen succeeds Conservative Poul Schlüter as Prime Minister of Denmark.
events.html: January 25 – Social Democrat Poul Nyrup Rasmussen succeeds Conservative Poul Schlüter as Prime Minister of Denmark.

events.text: January 26 – Václav Havel is elected President of the Czech Republic.
events.html: January 26 – Václav Havel is elected President of the Czech Republic.

events.text: February 4 – Members of the right-wing Austrian Freedom Party of Austria split to form the Liberal Forum in protest against the increasing nationalistic bent of the party.
events.html: February 4 – Members of the right-wing Austrian Freedom Party of Austria split to form the Liberal Forum in protest against the increasing nationalistic bent of the party.

events.text: February 5 – Belgium becomes a federal monarchy rather than a unitary kingdom.
events.html: February 5 – Belgium becomes a federal monarchy rather than a unitary kingdom.

events.text:
February 10
Lien Chan is named by Lee Teng-hui to succeed Hau Pei-tsun as Premier of the Republic of China.
Mani pulite scandal: Italian legislator Claudio Martelli resigns, followed by various politicians over the next two weeks.
events.html:
February 10
  • Lien Chan is named by Lee Teng-hui to succeed Hau Pei-tsun as Premier of the Republic of China.
  • Mani pulite scandal: Italian legislator Claudio Martelli resigns, followed by various politicians over the next two weeks.

events.html: Mani pulite scandal: Italian legislator Claudio Martelli resigns, followed by various politicians over the next two weeks.

events.text:
February 14
Glafcos Clerides defeats incumbent George Vasiliou in the Cypriot presidential election.
Albert Zafy defeats Didier Ratsiraka in the Madagascar presidential election.
events.html:
February 14
  • Glafcos Clerides defeats incumbent George Vasiliou in the Cypriot presidential election.
  • Albert Zafy defeats Didier Ratsiraka in the Madagascar presidential election.

events.html: Albert Zafy defeats Didier Ratsiraka in the Madagascar presidential election.

events.text: February 22 – United Nations Security Council Resolution 808 is voted on, deciding that "an international tribunal shall be established" to prosecute violations of international law in Yugoslavia. The tribunal is established on May 25 by Resolution 827.
events.html: February 22 – United Nations Security Council Resolution 808 is voted on, deciding that "an international tribunal shall be established" to prosecute violations of international law in Yugoslavia. The tribunal is established on May 25 by Resolution 827.

events.text: February 24 – Prime Minister of Canada Brian Mulroney announces his resignation (effective June 25) amidst political and economic turmoil.
events.html: February 24 – Prime Minister of Canada Brian Mulroney announces his resignation (effective June 25) amidst political and economic turmoil.

events.text: February 26 – World Trade Center bombing: In New York City, a van bomb parked below the North Tower of the World Trade Center explodes, killing six and injuring over one thousand.
events.html: February 26 – World Trade Center bombing: In New York City, a van bomb parked below the North Tower of the World Trade Center explodes, killing six and injuring over one thousand.

events.text: March 5 – Macedonian Palair Flight 301, an F-100 on a flight to Zürich, crashes shortly after take-off from Skopje, killing 83 of the 97 on board.
events.html: March 5 – Macedonian Palair Flight 301, an F-100 on a flight to Zürich, crashes shortly after take-off from Skopje, killing 83 of the 97 on board.

events.text: March 8 – The Moon moves into its nearest point to Earth, called perigee, at the same time as its fullest phase of the Lunar Cycle. The Moon appears to be 14% bigger and 30% brighter than the year's other full moons. The next time these two events coincided will be 2008.[2]
events.html: March 8 – The Moon moves into its nearest point to Earth, called perigee, at the same time as its fullest phase of the Lunar Cycle. The Moon appears to be 14% bigger and 30% brighter than the year's other full moons. The next time these two events coincided will be 2008.[2]

events.text: March 11 – Janet Reno is confirmed by the United States Senate and sworn in the next day, becoming the first female Attorney General of the United States.
events.html: March 11 – Janet Reno is confirmed by the United States Senate and sworn in the next day, becoming the first female Attorney General of the United States.

events.text:
March 12
1993 Bombay bombings: Several bombs explode in Bombay, India, killing 257 and injuring hundreds more.
North Korea nuclear weapons program: North Korea announces that it plans to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and refuses to allow inspectors access to nuclear sites.
events.html:
March 12
  • 1993 Bombay bombings: Several bombs explode in Bombay, India, killing 257 and injuring hundreds more.
  • North Korea nuclear weapons program: North Korea announces that it plans to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and refuses to allow inspectors access to nuclear sites.

events.text: 1993 Bombay bombings: Several bombs explode in Bombay, India, killing 257 and injuring hundreds more.

events.html: North Korea nuclear weapons program: North Korea announces that it plans to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and refuses to allow inspectors access to nuclear sites.

events.text: March 13–15 – The Great Blizzard of 1993 strikes the eastern U.S., bringing record snowfall and other severe weather all the way from Cuba to Quebec; it reportedly kills 184.
events.html: March 13–15 – The Great Blizzard of 1993 strikes the eastern U.S., bringing record snowfall and other severe weather all the way from Cuba to Quebec; it reportedly kills 184.

events.text: March 13 – 1993 Australian federal election: Paul Keating's Labor Government is re-elected with an increased majority, defeating the Liberal/National Coalition led by John Hewson.[3]
events.html: March 13 – 1993 Australian federal election: Paul Keating's Labor Government is re-elected with an increased majority, defeating the Liberal/National Coalition led by John Hewson.[3]

events.text: March 17 – The Kurdistan Workers' Party announces a unilateral ceasefire in Iraq.
events.html: March 17 – The Kurdistan Workers' Party announces a unilateral ceasefire in Iraq.

events.text:
March 24
The Israeli Knesset elects Ezer Weizman as President of Israel.
South Africa officially abandons its nuclear weapons programme. President de Klerk announces that the country's six warheads had already been dismantled in 1989.

March 24
  • The Israeli Knesset elects Ezer Weizman as President of Israel.
  • South Africa officially abandons its nuclear weapons programme. President de Klerk announces that the country's six warheads had already been dismantled in 1989.

events.text:
March 27
Jiang Zemin becomes President of the People's Republic of China.
Following a rash of integrist murders (including those of foreigners), Algeria breaks diplomatic relations with Iran, accusing the country of interfering in its interior affairs.
Mahamane Ousmane is elected president of Niger.

  • Following a rash of integrist murders (including those of foreigners), Algeria breaks diplomatic relations with Iran, accusing the country of interfering in its interior affairs.

events.text: March 28 – 1993 French legislative election: Rally for the Republic (Gaullist party) wins a majority and Édouard Balladur becomes Prime Minister.
events.html: March 28 – 1993 French legislative election: Rally for the Republic (Gaullist party) wins a majority and Édouard Balladur becomes Prime Minister.

events.text: March 29 – The 65th Academy Awards, hosted by Billy Crystal, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, with Unforgiven winning Best Picture.
events.html: March 29 – The 65th Academy Awards, hosted by Billy Crystal, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, with Unforgiven winning Best Picture.

events.text: April–May – 1993 Four Corners hantavirus outbreak: A dozen people are killed by the newly recognised Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome, mainly in the Southwestern United States.
events.html: April–May – 1993 Four Corners hantavirus outbreak: A dozen people are killed by the newly recognised Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome, mainly in the Southwestern United States.

events.text: April–October – Great Flood of 1993: The Mississippi and Missouri Rivers flood large portions of the American Midwest.
events.html: April–October – Great Flood of 1993: The Mississippi and Missouri Rivers flood large portions of the American Midwest.

events.text: April 1 – The Vatican orders the moving of the Carmelite convent at Auschwitz.
events.html: April 1 – The Vatican orders the moving of the Carmelite convent at Auschwitz.

events.text: April 8 – The Republic of Macedonia is admitted to the United Nations.
events.html: April 8 – The Republic of Macedonia is admitted to the United Nations.

events.text: April 10 – African National Congress activist Chris Hani is assassinated in South Africa.[4]
events.html: April 10 – African National Congress activist Chris Hani is assassinated in South Africa.[4]

events.text: April 16 – Bosnian War: the enclave of Srebrenica is declared a UN-protected "safe area".
events.html: April 16 – Bosnian War: the enclave of Srebrenica is declared a UN-protected "safe area".

events.text: April 19 – Waco siege: A 51-day stand-off at the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Texas, ends with a fire that kills 76 people, including David Koresh.
events.html: April 19 – Waco siege: A 51-day stand-off at the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Texas, ends with a fire that kills 76 people, including David Koresh.

events.text: April 20 – The Council for National Academic Awards in the United Kingdom is wound up.
events.html: April 20 – The Council for National Academic Awards in the United Kingdom is wound up.

events.text: April 21 – The Supreme Court in La Paz, Bolivia, sentences former dictator Luis Garcia Meza to 30 years in jail without parole for murder, theft, fraud and violating the constitution.
events.html: April 21 – The Supreme Court in La Paz, Bolivia, sentences former dictator Luis Garcia Meza to 30 years in jail without parole for murder, theft, fraud and violating the constitution.

events.text:
April 23
The World Health Organization declares tuberculosis a global emergency.
Eritreans vote overwhelmingly for independence from Ethiopia in a United Nations-monitored referendum, the Eritrean independence referendum.
events.html:
April 23
  • The World Health Organization declares tuberculosis a global emergency.
  • Eritreans vote overwhelmingly for independence from Ethiopia in a United Nations-monitored referendum, the Eritrean independence referendum.

events.text: April 26 – Oscar Luigi Scalfaro appoints Carlo Azeglio Ciampi Prime Minister of Italy.
events.html: April 26 – Oscar Luigi Scalfaro appoints Carlo Azeglio Ciampi Prime Minister of Italy.

events.text:
April 27
Eritrea: Eritrean independence is declared as a result of a referendum held with United Nations verification.
1993 Yemeni parliamentary election: The General People's Congress wins a plurality of 121 seats.
All members of the Zambia national football team die in a plane crash off Libreville, Gabon en route to Dakar, Senegal.
events.html:
April 27
  • Eritrea: Eritrean independence is declared as a result of a referendum held with United Nations verification.
  • 1993 Yemeni parliamentary election: The General People's Congress wins a plurality of 121 seats.
  • All members of the Zambia national football team die in a plane crash off Libreville, Gabon en route to Dakar, Senegal.

events.html: All members of the Zambia national football team die in a plane crash off Libreville, Gabon en route to Dakar, Senegal.

events.text: April 30 – Tennis player Monica Seles – at this time World No. 1 in women's tennis – is stabbed during a match in Hamburg.
events.html: April 30 – Tennis player Monica Seles – at this time World No. 1 in women's tennis – is stabbed during a match in Hamburg.

events.text:
May 1
A Tamil Tigers suicide bomber assassinates President Ranasinghe Premadasa of Sri Lanka.
Dingiri Banda Wijetunga became the third executive president of Sri Lanka.
events.html:
May 1
  • A Tamil Tigers suicide bomber assassinates President Ranasinghe Premadasa of Sri Lanka.
  • Dingiri Banda Wijetunga became the third executive president of Sri Lanka.

events.text: May 4 – UNOSOM II assumes the Somalian duties of the dissolved UNITAF.
events.html: May 4 – UNOSOM II assumes the Somalian duties of the dissolved UNITAF.

events.text: May 9 – Juan Carlos Wasmosy becomes the first democratically elected President of Paraguay in nearly 40 years. He beat Domingo Laíno in the 1993 Paraguayan general election.
events.html: May 9 – Juan Carlos Wasmosy becomes the first democratically elected President of Paraguay in nearly 40 years. He beat Domingo Laíno in the 1993 Paraguayan general election.

events.text: May 15 – Niamh Kavanagh wins the Eurovision Song Contest for Ireland with In Your Eyes.
events.html: May 15 – Niamh Kavanagh wins the Eurovision Song Contest for Ireland with In Your Eyes.

events.text: May 16 – The Grand National Assembly of Turkey elects Prime Minister Süleyman Demirel as President of Turkey. After Demirel becomes president, the acting Prime Minister of Turkey is Erdal İnönü of Social Democratic Populist Party for 40 days.
events.html: May 16 – The Grand National Assembly of Turkey elects Prime Minister Süleyman Demirel as President of Turkey. After Demirel becomes president, the acting Prime Minister of Turkey is Erdal İnönü of Social Democratic Populist Party for 40 days.

events.text: May 24 – Eritrea gains independence from Ethiopia.
events.html: May 24 – Eritrea gains independence from Ethiopia.

events.text: May 25 – The International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia is created in The Hague.
events.html: May 25 – The International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia is created in The Hague.

events.text: May 28 – Eritrea and Monaco gain entry to the United Nations.
events.html: May 28 – Eritrea and Monaco gain entry to the United Nations.

events.text:
June 1
Large protests erupt against Slobodan Milošević's regime in Belgrade; opposition leader Vuk Drašković and his wife Danica are arrested.
President of Guatemala Jorge Serrano Elías is forced to flee the country after an attempted self-coup.
1993 Burundian presidential election: The first multiparty elections in Burundi since the country's independence lead to the election of Melchior Ndadaye, leader of the Front for Democracy in Burundi. The next day's legislative election sees his party win with an overwhelming majority.

  • 1993 Burundian presidential election: The first multiparty elections in Burundi since the country's independence lead to the election of Melchior Ndadaye, leader of the Front for Democracy in Burundi. The next day's legislative election sees his party win with an overwhelming majority.

events.text:
June 5
The National Assembly of Venezuela designates Ramón José Velásquez as successor of suspended President Carlos Andrés Pérez.
Twenty-four Pakistani troops in the United Nations forces are killed in Mogadishu, Somalia.

events.text: June 8 – The PKK-declared ceasefire ends in Iraq.
events.html: June 8 – The PKK-declared ceasefire ends in Iraq.

events.text:
June 9 – Jurassic Park is released.
The Montreal Canadiens win the Stanley Cup in game five against the Los Angeles Kings. It is to date the last time a Canadian team has won the Stanley Cup.

events.html: June 14 – Multipartyists win a referendum on the future of the one-party system in Malawi.

events.text: June 18 – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq refuses to allow UNSCOM weapons inspectors to install remote-controlled monitoring cameras at two missile engine test stands.
events.html: June 18 – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq refuses to allow UNSCOM weapons inspectors to install remote-controlled monitoring cameras at two missile engine test stands.

events.text: June 22 – Japan's New Party Sakigake breaks away from the Liberal Democratic Party.
events.html: June 22 – Japan's New Party Sakigake breaks away from the Liberal Democratic Party.

events.text:
June 24
Andrew Wiles wins worldwide fame after presenting his proof of Fermat's Last Theorem, a problem that had been unsolved for more than three centuries.
Following a campaign by the Campaign for Homosexual Law Reform, Dáil Éireann in the Republic of Ireland passes the Criminal Law (Sexual Offences) Act, reforming the country's sodomy law to decriminalise consensual homosexual acts.
events.html:
June 24

events.text:
June 25
Kim Campbell becomes the 19th, and first female, Prime Minister of Canada.
Tansu Çiller of True Path Party forms the new government of Turkey.
Zoran Lilić succeeds Dobrica Ćosić as President of Yugoslavia.
The litas is introduced as the new currency of Lithuania.
Jacques Attali resigns as President of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

events.text: Zoran Lilić succeeds Dobrica Ćosić as President of Yugoslavia.
events.html: Zoran Lilić succeeds Dobrica Ćosić as President of Yugoslavia.

events.text: The litas is introduced as the new currency of Lithuania.

events.text: Jacques Attali resigns as President of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
events.html: Jacques Attali resigns as President of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

events.text: June 26–28 – Typhoon Koryn causes massive damage to the Philippines, China and Macau.
events.html: June 26–28 – Typhoon Koryn causes massive damage to the Philippines, China and Macau.

events.text: June 27 – U.S. President Bill Clinton orders a cruise missile attack on Iraqi intelligence headquarters in the Al-Mansur District of Baghdad, in response to an Iraqi plot to assassinate former U.S. President George H. W. Bush during his visit to Kuwait in mid-April.
events.html: June 27 – U.S. President Bill Clinton orders a cruise missile attack on Iraqi intelligence headquarters in the Al-Mansur District of Baghdad, in response to an Iraqi plot to assassinate former U.S. President George H. W. Bush during his visit to Kuwait in mid-April.

events.text:
July 2
An Islamist mob sets fire to the hotel where The Satanic Verses translator Aziz Nesin resides in Sivas, Turkey, killing 37.
A floating chapel sinks in Bocaue, Bulacan, killing 266 people.
events.html:
July 2

  • A floating chapel sinks in Bocaue, Bulacan, killing 266 people.

July 5
Iraq disarmament crisis: UN inspection teams leave Iraq. Iraq then agrees to UNSCOM demands and the inspection teams return.
Electrochemist Faiza Al-Kharafi is appointed rector (president) of Kuwait University, the first woman to head a major university in the Middle East.

events.text: July 7 – Hurricane Calvin lands in Mexico. It is the second Pacific hurricane on record to land in Mexico in July and kills 34.
events.html: July 7 – Hurricane Calvin lands in Mexico. It is the second Pacific hurricane on record to land in Mexico in July and kills 34.

events.text: July 12 – The 7.7 Mw  Hokkaidō earthquake affected northern Japan with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe) and triggers a devastating tsunami that kills 230 on the small island of Okushiri, Hokkaido.
events.html: July 12 – The 7.7 Mw  Hokkaidō earthquake affected northern Japan with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe) and triggers a devastating tsunami that kills 230 on the small island of Okushiri, Hokkaido.

events.text: July 15 – 1993 child sexual abuse accusations against Michael Jackson: Evan Chandler institutes legal accusations against singer Michael Jackson of sexually molesting Jordan Chandler, Evan's 13-year-old son in the United States.
events.html: July 15 – 1993 child sexual abuse accusations against Michael Jackson: Evan Chandler institutes legal accusations against singer Michael Jackson of sexually molesting Jordan Chandler, Evan's 13-year-old son in the United States.

events.text: July 19 – 1993 Japanese general election: The loss of majority of the Liberal Democratic Party results in a coalition taking power.
events.html: July 19 – 1993 Japanese general election: The loss of majority of the Liberal Democratic Party results in a coalition taking power.

events.text: July 25 – In a terrorist attack members of the Azanian People's Liberation Army open fire on a congregation inside St James Church in Kenilworth, Cape Town, killing eleven and injuring fifty.[4][5]
events.html: July 25 – In a terrorist attack members of the Azanian People's Liberation Army open fire on a congregation inside St James Church in Kenilworth, Cape Town, killing eleven and injuring fifty.[4][5]

events.text:
July 26
Miguel Indurain wins the 1993 Tour de France.
Asiana Airlines Flight 733 crashes into Mt. Ungeo in Haenam, South Korea; 68 are killed.
events.html:
July 26
  • Miguel Indurain wins the 1993 Tour de France.
  • Asiana Airlines Flight 733 crashes into Mt. Ungeo in Haenam, South Korea; 68 are killed.

events.html: Asiana Airlines Flight 733 crashes into Mt. Ungeo in Haenam, South Korea; 68 are killed.

events.text: July 29 – The Israeli Supreme Court acquits accused Nazi death camp guard John Demjanjuk of all charges and he is set free.
events.html: July 29 – The Israeli Supreme Court acquits accused Nazi death camp guard John Demjanjuk of all charges and he is set free.

events.text: August – The European Exchange Rate Mechanism margin was expanded to 15% to accommodate speculation against the French franc and other currencies.[6]
events.html: August – The European Exchange Rate Mechanism margin was expanded to 15% to accommodate speculation against the French franc and other currencies.[6]

events.text: August 4 – The Japanese government issues the Kono Statement, acknowledging the comfort women's (sex slaves) deportation.
events.html: August 4 – The Japanese government issues the Kono Statement, acknowledging the comfort women's (sex slaves) deportation.

events.text: August 5 – The discovery of the Tel Dan Stele, the first archaeological confirmation of the existence of the Davidic line, is announced.
events.html: August 5 – The discovery of the Tel Dan Stele, the first archaeological confirmation of the existence of the Davidic line, is announced.

events.text: August 9 – King Albert II of Belgium is sworn into office nine days after the death of his brother, King Baudouin I.
events.html: August 9 – King Albert II of Belgium is sworn into office nine days after the death of his brother, King Baudouin I.

events.text: August 13 – More than 130 die in the collapse of Royal Plaza Hotel at Nakhon Ratchasima in Thailand's worst hotel disaster.
events.html: August 13 – More than 130 die in the collapse of Royal Plaza Hotel at Nakhon Ratchasima in Thailand's worst hotel disaster.

events.text: August 18 – The 14th-century Kapellbrücke covered wooden truss bridge in Lucerne (Switzerland) is largely destroyed by fire.
events.html: August 18 – The 14th-century Kapellbrücke covered wooden truss bridge in Lucerne (Switzerland) is largely destroyed by fire.

events.text: August 21 – NASA loses radio contact with the Mars Observer orbiter 3 days before the spacecraft is scheduled to enter orbit around Mars.
events.html: August 21 – NASA loses radio contact with the Mars Observer orbiter 3 days before the spacecraft is scheduled to enter orbit around Mars.

events.text: August 28 – Ong Teng Cheong becomes the first President of Singapore elected by the population.
events.html: August 28 – Ong Teng Cheong becomes the first President of Singapore elected by the population.

events.text: August 31 – Russia completes removing its troops from Lithuania.
events.html: August 31 – Russia completes removing its troops from Lithuania.

events.text: September that never ended in Usenet community.
events.html: September that never ended in Usenet community.

events.text:
September 13
1993 Norwegian parliamentary election: The Labour Party wins a plurality of the seats and Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland retains office.
Oslo I Accord: Following initially secret talks from earlier in the year, PLO leader Yasser Arafat and Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin shake hands in Washington, D.C. after signing a peace accord.
events.html:
September 13
  • 1993 Norwegian parliamentary election: The Labour Party wins a plurality of the seats and Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland retains office.

events.text: September 17 – Russian troops withdraw from Poland.
events.html: September 17 – Russian troops withdraw from Poland.

events.text: September 19 – 1993 Polish parliamentary election: A coalition of the Democratic Left Alliance and the Polish People's Party led by Waldemar Pawlak comes into power.
events.html: September 19 – 1993 Polish parliamentary election: A coalition of the Democratic Left Alliance and the Polish People's Party led by Waldemar Pawlak comes into power.

events.text: September 22 – Big Bayou Canot train disaster: A bridge collapses as the  Amtrak Sunset Limited crosses it, killing 47.
events.html: September 22 – Big Bayou Canot train disaster: A bridge collapses as the Amtrak Sunset Limited crosses it, killing 47.

events.text: September 23 – The International Olympic Committee selects Sydney, Australia, to host the 2000 Summer Olympics.[7]
events.html: September 23 – The International Olympic Committee selects Sydney, Australia, to host the 2000 Summer Olympics.[7]

events.text: September 24 – The Cambodian monarchy is restored, with Norodom Sihanouk as king.
events.html: September 24 – The Cambodian monarchy is restored, with Norodom Sihanouk as king.

events.text:
September 26
The first mission in Biosphere 2 ends after two years.
PoSAT-1 (the first Portuguese satellite) is launched on board French rocket Ariane 4.

events.html: September 27 – War in Abkhazia: Fall of Sukhumi – Eduard Shevardnadze accuses Russia of passive complicity.

events.text: September 30 – The 6.2 Mw  Latur earthquake shakes Maharashtra, India with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe) killing 9,748 and injuring 30,000.
events.html: September 30 – The 6.2 Mw  Latur earthquake shakes Maharashtra, India with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe) killing 9,748 and injuring 30,000.

events.text: October 3–4– Battle of Mogadishu: The U.S. Army conducts Operation Gothic Serpent in the city of Mogadishu, Somalia, using Task Force Ranger. Two U.S. Army UH-60 Blackhawks are shot down and the operation leaves over 1,000 Somalians dead and over 74 Americans wounded in action, 18 killed and 1 captured.

events.text: October 4 – The Russian constitutional crisis culminates with Russian military and security forces, using tanks and clearing the White House of Russia Parliament building by force, quashing a mass uprising against President Boris Yeltsin.
events.html: October 4 – The Russian constitutional crisis culminates with Russian military and security forces, using tanks and clearing the White House of Russia Parliament building by force, quashing a mass uprising against President Boris Yeltsin.

events.text: October 5 – China performs a nuclear test, ending a worldwide de facto moratorium.
events.html: October 5 – China performs a nuclear test, ending a worldwide de facto moratorium.

events.text: October 10 – The South Korean ferry Seohae capsizes off Pusan, South Korea; 292 are killed.
events.html: October 10 – The South Korean ferry Seohae capsizes off Pusan, South Korea; 292 are killed.

events.text: October 11–28 – The UNMIH is prevented from entering Haiti by its military-led regime. On October 18, United Nations economic sanctions (abolished in August) are reinstated. U.S. President Bill Clinton sends 6 American warships to enforce them.
events.html: October 11–28 – The UNMIH is prevented from entering Haiti by its military-led regime. On October 18, United Nations economic sanctions (abolished in August) are reinstated. U.S. President Bill Clinton sends 6 American warships to enforce them.

events.text:
October 13
1993 Greek legislative election: Andreas Papandreou begins his second term as Prime Minister of Greece.
The fifth summit of the Francophonie opens in Mauritius.
The 1993 Finisterre earthquakes in Papua New Guinea kills at least 60 due to landslides.[8]

October 13

events.text: October 21 – A coup in Burundi results in the death of president Melchior Ndadaye and sparks the Burundi Civil War.
events.html: October 21 – A coup in Burundi results in the death of president Melchior Ndadaye and sparks the Burundi Civil War.

events.text: October 25 – 1993 Canadian federal election: Jean Chrétien and his Liberal Party defeat the governing Progressive Conservative Party, which falls to a historic low of two seats.
events.html: October 25 – 1993 Canadian federal election: Jean Chrétien and his Liberal Party defeat the governing Progressive Conservative Party, which falls to a historic low of two seats.

events.text: November 1 – The Maastricht Treaty takes effect, formally establishing the European Union.
events.html: November 1 – The Maastricht Treaty takes effect, formally establishing the European Union.

events.text: November 4 – Jean Chretien becomes the 20th Prime Minister of Canada.
events.html: November 4 – Jean Chretien becomes the 20th Prime Minister of Canada.

events.text: November 5 – The Parliament of the United Kingdom passes the Railways Act 1993, setting out the procedures for privatisation of British Rail.
events.html: November 5 – The Parliament of the United Kingdom passes the Railways Act 1993, setting out the procedures for privatisation of British Rail.

events.text: November 9 – Bosnian Croat forces destroy the Stari Most, or Old Bridge of Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, by tank fire.
events.html: November 9 – Bosnian Croat forces destroy the Stari Most, or Old Bridge of Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, by tank fire.

events.text: November 12 – London Convention: Marine dumping of radioactive waste is outlawed.
events.html: November 12 – London Convention: Marine dumping of radioactive waste is outlawed.

events.text: November 17–22 – The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) passes the legislative houses in the United States, Canada and Mexico.
events.html: November 17–22 – The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) passes the legislative houses in the United States, Canada and Mexico.

events.text: November 17 – In Nigeria, General Sani Abacha ousts the government of Ernest Shonekan in a military coup.
events.html: November 17 – In Nigeria, General Sani Abacha ousts the government of Ernest Shonekan in a military coup.

November 18
In a status referendum, Puerto Rico residents vote with a slim margin to maintain Commonwealth status.
The first meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit opens in Seattle.

events.html: November 20 – An Avioimpex Yakovlev Yak-42D crashes into Mount Trojani near Ohrid, Macedonia. All 8 crew members and 115 of the 116 passengers are killed.

An agreement establishing the Permanent Commission for East African Co-operation is signed.
U.S. President Bill Clinton signs the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act.

STS-61: NASA launches the Space Shuttle Endeavour on a mission to repair an optical flaw in the Hubble Space Telescope.[9]
Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar is gunned down by police.[10]

events.text:
December 7
In Garden City, New York, six people are murdered and 19 injured in the Long Island Rail Road massacre, a racially motivated mass shooting perpetrated by Colin Ferguson, a black Jamaican immigrant.[13]
The 32-member Transitional Executive Committee holds its first meeting[14] in Cape Town, marking the first meeting of an official government body in South Africa with Black members.
President of Ivory Coast Félix Houphouët-Boigny dies at 88, the oldest African head of state.[15] He is succeeded four days later by Henri Konan Bédié.[16]

events.text:
December 30
The Congress Party gains a parliamentary majority in India after the defection of 10 Janata Dal party lawmakers.
Representatives of Israel and the Holy See sign the Fundamental Agreement Between the Holy See and the State of Israel, preparing for the establishment of diplomatic relations.[28]
Argentina passes a measure allowing President Carlos Menem and all future presidents to run for a second consecutive term. It also shortens presidential terms to 4 years and removes the requirement for the president to be Roman Catholic.[29]
